title: Glioblastoma (GBM), IDH-wildtype, WHO Grade 4
icd10: C71.5 (Malignant neoplasm of other parts of cerebrum)
C71.8 (Malignant neoplasm of overlapping sites of brain)
D49.6 (Neoplasm of unspecified behavior of brain)
scope: ** Comprehensive management of newly diagnosed and recurrent glioblastoma (IDH-wildtype, WHO grade 4) in adults. Covers initial presentation and stabilization, neuroimaging evaluation (MRI with gadolinium, perfusion MRI, MR spectroscopy), histopathologic and molecular profiling (MGMT promoter methylation, TERT promoter mutation, EGFR amplification, +7/-10 chromosome changes), surgical planning (maximal safe resection, stereotactic biopsy), standard Stupp protocol (concurrent temozolomide + radiation followed by adjuvant temozolomide), tumor treating fields (TTFields/Optune), recurrence management (bevacizumab, lomustine, re-resection), supportive care (dexamethasone, seizure management), and palliative care integration. Excludes pediatric gliomas, IDH-mutant astrocytomas, oligodendrogliomas, and brain metastases (separate templates).

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (gadolinium) (CPT 70553)

Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurosurgery STAT consultation for surgical candidacy evaluation, maximal safe resection planning, and ICP management for all patients with suspected high-grade glioma
Neuro-oncology consultation for molecular profiling interpretation, Stupp protocol initiation, and long-term treatment planning
Radiation oncology consultation for treatment planning (60 Gy in 30 fractions or hypofractionated per age/KPS) to begin within 3-6 weeks post-surgery
Multidisciplinary tumor board presentation for coordinated treatment planning including neurosurgery, neuro-oncology, radiation oncology, neuropathology, and neuroradiology

Neuropathology consultation for comprehensive molecular profiling including IDH mutation, MGMT promoter methylation, TERT promoter mutation, EGFR amplification, +7/-10 chromosome status, and integrated WHO 2021 classification
Palliative care consultation for symptom management, goals of care discussion, and advance directive completion given median survival of 14-16 months
Physical therapy for mobility assessment, fall prevention given steroid myopathy and neurologic deficits, and exercise program to mitigate deconditioning
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive compensation strategies, and home safety evaluation
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation if posterior fossa or brainstem involvement, and language assessment if dominant hemisphere tumor
Social work consultation for insurance authorization, disability paperwork, caregiver support, and community resource coordination
Neuropsychology evaluation for baseline cognitive assessment before radiation and chemotherapy to monitor treatment-related decline
Genetic counseling if age <45 years, family history of cancer, or clinical suspicion for Li-Fraumeni or other cancer predisposition syndrome
Psychiatry/psychology referral for depression, anxiety, and adjustment disorder management given diagnosis of malignant brain tumor
Ophthalmology consultation if visual field deficits, papilledema, or tumor near visual pathways
Endocrinology consultation if persistent steroid-induced hyperglycemia difficult to manage or hypothalamic/pituitary involvement
Clinical trials evaluation for eligible patients at all stages including newly diagnosed (novel combinations) and recurrence (immunotherapy, targeted agents, novel delivery)

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for new or worsening headache, sudden weakness, vision changes, speech difficulty, or seizures (may indicate tumor progression, hemorrhage, or increased intracranial pressure)
Do not drive until cleared by neurology and neurosurgery due to seizure risk, visual field deficits, and cognitive impairment
Do not stop dexamethasone abruptly as this may cause adrenal crisis; follow prescribed taper schedule exactly
Take temozolomide on empty stomach 1 hour before bedtime with antiemetic pre-medication to minimize nausea
Report any fever, unusual bruising, or signs of infection while on chemotherapy as this may indicate dangerous myelosuppression requiring urgent evaluation
For TTFields (Optune) users: maintain device use for at least 18 hours/day for optimal benefit; inspect scalp for skin irritation daily; contact device support team for technical issues
Keep a symptom diary documenting headaches, seizures, weakness, cognitive changes, and mood to track treatment response
Discuss advance directive and healthcare proxy designation given diagnosis and expected disease course
Wear medical alert identification indicating brain tumor diagnosis and seizure risk
Avoid live vaccines during chemotherapy and steroid therapy due to immunosuppression

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Low-sodium diet while on dexamethasone to reduce fluid retention, edema, and hypertension
Blood sugar monitoring and diabetic diet while on steroids to prevent steroid-induced hyperglycemia complications
Regular low-impact exercise (walking, swimming, yoga) as tolerated to maintain strength, reduce steroid myopathy, and improve mood and quality of life
Fall precautions at home including removal of trip hazards, use of handrails, non-slip mats, and night lights given focal deficits, steroid myopathy, and seizure risk
Smoking cessation to optimize wound healing, radiation response, and reduce thrombotic risk
Alcohol avoidance during chemotherapy to prevent hepatotoxicity and avoid seizure threshold lowering
CPAP compliance if obstructive sleep apnea present to prevent nocturnal hypoxia which may worsen cerebral edema
Sun protection while on temozolomide due to photosensitivity risk
Adequate hydration (2-3 L/day unless fluid restricted) during chemotherapy and steroid use to support renal function and prevent constipation

differential.features: History of systemic malignancy; often multiple lesions (vs. GBM usually single); well-demarcated ring enhancement; located at gray-white junction; less infiltrative
differential.tests: CT chest/abdomen/pelvis; PET/CT for primary site; tissue biopsy (cytokeratin, TTF-1, melanoma markers); typically no IDH mutation, no GFAP expression

differential.features: Periventricular homogeneous enhancement (not ring-enhancing unless HIV); restricted diffusion on DWI; responds dramatically to corticosteroids ("ghost tumor"); immunocompromised patients
differential.tests: AVOID steroids before biopsy (may render non-diagnostic); DWI showing restricted diffusion; CSF flow cytometry; stereotactic biopsy; HIV testing; slit lamp exam for vitreous involvement

differential.features: Ring-enhancing with central restricted diffusion on DWI (bright DWI, dark ADC in cavity -- GBM does NOT show central restricted diffusion); thin smooth rim; fever, leukocytosis; recent ENT/dental/cardiac source
differential.tests: DWI is key differentiator (central restriction = abscess); MR spectroscopy (amino acid peaks: succinate, acetate); blood cultures; echocardiogram for endocarditis

differential.features: Younger patients (30-50 years); less aggressive imaging appearance; may lack ring enhancement; frontal lobe predilection; FLAIR mismatch sign in grade 2
differential.tests: IDH1/2 mutation testing (positive); ATRX loss; p53 overexpression; no EGFR amplification; no +7/-10; prognosis significantly better than IDH-wildtype GBM

differential.features: "Fried egg" histology; calcifications common; cortical involvement; T2-FLAIR mismatch less common; typically younger patients
differential.tests: IDH mutation (positive); 1p/19q codeletion (defining feature); calcifications on CT; distinct molecular profile from GBM

differential.features: Younger patients; incomplete ring enhancement ("open ring sign"); less mass effect relative to size; clinical history of MS symptoms; other demyelinating lesions
differential.tests: MRI: open ring enhancement; CSF oligoclonal bands; MOG/AQP4 antibodies; clinical dissemination in time and space; response to corticosteroids with resolution

differential.features: HIV/AIDS with CD4 <100; multiple ring-enhancing lesions; basal ganglia predilection; eccentric target sign
differential.tests: Toxoplasma IgG; CD4 count; empiric treatment trial (response in 10-14 days); if no response then biopsy; Thallium SPECT

differential.features: History of prior brain radiation (typically 6-24 months post-treatment); enhancing lesion at prior radiation site; challenging to distinguish from recurrent GBM on conventional MRI
differential.tests: MR perfusion (low rCBV in necrosis vs. high in tumor); MR spectroscopy (elevated lipid/lactate, low choline in necrosis); FET-PET; biopsy if equivocal

differential.features: Vascular territory distribution; ring enhancement at 1-4 weeks post-stroke; clinical history of acute onset; DWI conforming to vascular territory
differential.tests: Vascular territory distribution; DWI/ADC map evolution; clinical history; MRA/CTA showing vascular occlusion

differential.features: Diffuse infiltration involving >=3 lobes; minimal or no enhancement; widespread T2/FLAIR abnormality; no discrete mass
differential.tests: MRI showing diffuse T2/FLAIR without focal enhancing mass; biopsy from most abnormal region; molecular profiling

evidence.recommendation: Maximal safe resection improves overall survival in GBM
evidence.source: Lacroix et al. J Neurosurg 2001; Sanai et al. J Neurosurg 2011

evidence.recommendation: 5-ALA fluorescence-guided surgery improves extent of resection
evidence.source: Stummer et al. Lancet Oncol 2006

evidence.recommendation: Concurrent temozolomide + radiation (Stupp protocol) standard of care for newly diagnosed GBM
evidence.source: Stupp et al. NEJM 2005; Stupp et al. Lancet Oncol 2009 (5-year data)

evidence.recommendation: MGMT promoter methylation predicts temozolomide response and overall survival
evidence.source: Hegi et al. NEJM 2005

evidence.recommendation: Tumor Treating Fields (TTFields) with adjuvant temozolomide improves OS in newly diagnosed GBM
evidence.source: Stupp et al. JAMA 2017 (EF-14 trial)

evidence.recommendation: Hypofractionated RT (40 Gy/15 fractions) + temozolomide beneficial in elderly GBM
evidence.source: Perry et al. NEJM 2017

evidence.recommendation: Temozolomide alone vs. RT alone in elderly GBM; treatment guided by MGMT status
evidence.source: Wick et al. Lancet Oncol 2012 (NOA-08); Malmstrom et al. Lancet Oncol 2012 (Nordic trial)

evidence.recommendation: Bevacizumab for recurrent GBM: PFS benefit, no OS benefit
evidence.source: Friedman et al. J Clin Oncol 2009; Wick et al. Lancet Oncol 2017 (EORTC 26101)

evidence.recommendation: Bevacizumab in newly diagnosed GBM: PFS benefit, no OS benefit
evidence.source: Chinot et al. NEJM 2014 (AVAglio); Gilbert et al. NEJM 2014 (RTOG 0825)

evidence.recommendation: WHO 2021 classification: IDH-wildtype glioblastoma defined by molecular criteria
evidence.source: Louis et al. Neuro-Oncology 2021 (WHO CNS5)

evidence.recommendation: TERT promoter mutation, EGFR amplification, +7/-10 as molecular diagnostic criteria for GBM
evidence.source: Louis et al. Neuro-Oncology 2021 (WHO CNS5)

evidence.recommendation: Prophylactic AEDs NOT recommended in brain tumor patients without seizures
evidence.source: Glantz et al. Neurology 2000 (AAN Practice Parameter); reaffirmed

evidence.recommendation: Levetiracetam preferred AED in brain tumor patients (no CYP enzyme induction)
evidence.source: Rosati et al. J Neurooncol 2010; RANO guidelines

evidence.recommendation: DVT prophylaxis safe in brain tumor patients
evidence.source: Perry et al. Lancet 2010 (PRODIGE trial)

evidence.recommendation: Dexamethasone for vasogenic edema; use minimum effective dose and taper
evidence.source: Ryken et al. J Neurooncol 2010 (CNS systematic review)

evidence.recommendation: Pseudoprogression occurs in 20-30% of GBM patients post-chemoradiation, especially MGMT methylated
evidence.source: Brandsma et al. Lancet Oncol 2008; RANO criteria 2010

evidence.recommendation: RANO response criteria for glioblastoma clinical assessment
evidence.source: Wen et al. J Clin Oncol 2010

evidence.recommendation: Lomustine for recurrent GBM; combination with bevacizumab PFS benefit
evidence.source: Wick et al. Lancet Oncol 2017 (EORTC 26101)

evidence.recommendation: PJP prophylaxis recommended during concurrent chemoradiation
evidence.source: Expert consensus; NCCN guidelines

evidence.recommendation: Supratotal resection may improve outcomes beyond contrast-enhancing boundary
evidence.source: Li et al. World Neurosurg 2016; emerging evidence

evidence.recommendation: MR spectroscopy and perfusion MRI differentiate tumor from treatment effects
evidence.source: Law et al. AJNR 2003; various meta-analyses

evidence.recommendation: Memantine may reduce cognitive decline during brain radiation therapy
evidence.source: Brown et al. Neuro-Oncology 2013 (RTOG 0614)

evidence.recommendation: Methylphenidate for cancer-related fatigue
evidence.source: Lower et al. Cancer 2009; Minton et al. J Clin Oncol 2013 (Cochrane review)

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (motor, sensory, language, cognition, cranial nerves)
monitoring.action: STAT MRI if decline; increase dexamethasone; neurosurgery alert if herniation

monitoring.frequency: q6h while on dexamethasone (q1h if insulin drip)
monitoring.action: Sliding scale to basal-bolus insulin; endocrine consult if refractory

monitoring.frequency: Weekly during concurrent chemoradiation; Day 1 and Day 22 of each adjuvant TMZ cycle
monitoring.action: Hold temozolomide if ANC <1000 or platelets <50K; PJP prophylaxis if CD4 <200 or ALC <500

monitoring.frequency: q2 weeks during concurrent TMZ; monthly during adjuvant TMZ
monitoring.action: Dose reduce or hold temozolomide; hepatology consult if Grade 3-4 elevation
SIADH workup if <130; fluid restriction; hypertonic saline if <125 or symptomatic

monitoring.frequency: Post-op within 48h; 4 weeks post-RT (new baseline); then q2-3 months
monitoring.action: Tumor board discussion if progression suspected; advanced imaging (perfusion, spectroscopy, PET); rebiopsy if equivocal

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; q4h on floor; each clinic visit
monitoring.action: Antihypertensives; especially important if on bevacizumab (target <140/90)
KPS <40: consider transition to best supportive care/hospice
AED dose adjustment; consider cEEG if subclinical seizures suspected; verify medication compliance
Dietitian referral; consider appetite stimulants; evaluate for steroid myopathy vs. cachexia
Psychiatry/psychology referral; SSRI initiation (avoid CYP interactions); supportive care
Patient education; troubleshoot barriers; scalp care for contact dermatitis
24-hour urine if >2+; hold bevacizumab if nephrotic range (>3.5 g/24h)

disposition.criteria: GCS <=12; signs of herniation (pupil asymmetry, posturing, Cushing triad); acute hemorrhage into tumor; status epilepticus; post-craniotomy (first 24h per institutional protocol); respiratory compromise requiring intubation; hemodynamic instability

New diagnosis requiring workup and stabilization; symptomatic edema requiring IV dexamethasone with close glucose monitoring; post-craniotomy step-down from ICU (typically POD 1-2); seizures requiring AED optimization and observation; functional decline requiring inpatient rehabilitation planning
Known GBM with mild symptom worsening on stable regimen; MRI showing possible progression requiring multidisciplinary discussion; steroid dose adjustment with monitoring

Neurologically stable for >=24h; seizure-free >=24h on oral AED; oral dexamethasone taper plan established with written instructions; glucose management plan in place; pain controlled on oral medications; treatment plan established with scheduled appointments (neurosurgery, neuro-oncology, radiation oncology within 1-2 weeks); safe ambulation and ADLs or adequate caregiver; patient/family education completed

Need for neurosurgical expertise not available; tumor board or neuro-oncology consultation not available; need for specialized intraoperative monitoring (iMRI, awake craniotomy); clinical trial access at tertiary center

Significant post-operative neurologic deficits (hemiparesis, aphasia, cognitive impairment) requiring intensive rehabilitation before outpatient treatment can begin; KPS 40-60 with rehabilitation potential

End-stage GBM with progressive decline despite treatment; KPS <30; exhausted reasonable treatment options; patient/family goals aligned with comfort-focused care; no longer candidate for disease-directed therapy
